awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Developing and Validating a Physically Accurate Light-Scattering Model for the Rendering of Bird and Other Dinosaur Feathers
awd_abstract_narration:
Although computer graphics has become a crucial tool for scientific visualization (and many other fields such as medicine, industry, education, and communication), more realistic, fine-scale representations of the natural world are still sorely needed.  Rendering, a core component of computer graphics, uses models of light and material interaction to generate today's most photorealistic images, but there are many real-world materials yet to be fundamentally studied in this regard.  In ornithology and paleontology, for example, researchers continue to investigate feather micro-structures in an effort to discover how these produce color and iridescence, and to reveal the similarities and differences between feathers of modern birds and those of extinct dinosaurs, but to date no sufficiently sophisticated model has been developed to represent the complex, multi-scale interaction of light with feather sub-structures.  This interdisciplinary project will lead to the first computer-graphics appearance model specifically developed for feathers, by collecting and building on biophysical data to design a biologically realistic rendering method.  Additional broad impacts will derive from the project outcomes contributing to educational activities related to birds and other dinosaurs while transforming rendering capabilities to create photorealistic images of feathers and feathered creatures for scientific visualization, illustration, documentaries, and interactive graphics. 

The appearance of real-world feather anatomy is the result of light interactions with complex, patterned structures of varying scale.  Currently, fiber-shading models of mammalian hair and fur are often used for convenience, despite their quite different structural and mechanical properties; inherently, therefore, such models do not accurately recreate the scattering properties of feathers.  Furthermore, structural coloration, a wave-optics property not represented at all in fiber-shading models, is present in many feathers.  To address these deficiencies, novel material models will be developed by collecting and observing physical data of varying scales from feathers.  Broad taxonomic sampling will make manifest important variation among birds and facilitate imaging of a wide variety of microscopic structures.  Light-scattering data will be recorded to develop and validate the new physical material models.  Greater understanding of these multi-scale light interactions as well as the complex phenomenon of structural coloration holds potential to advance perspectives in several fields.  Visualizations and comparisons between living-bird feathers and non-avian dinosaur fossils will increase understanding of feather evolution, be applicable to studies of signaling and evolution of mate choice in ornithology, and improve sophistication of fiber and wave-optics models in computer graphics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has supported an interdisciplinary investigation of the structure of feathers and how they reflect light as well as the development of novel instrumentation and techniques for measuring optical scattering from real-world surfaces related to computer graphics and physically based rendering.  The appearance of feather anatomy is the result of light interactions with complex, patterned structures of varying scale and has not had a comprehensive shading model designed yet to use in scientific visualization, visual-effects, and other applications.  To gain understanding and improve techniques related to measuring and rendering real-world materials, efforts have included guided data collection; development of new acquisition hardware, software, and techniques; and investigation of new methods for material acquisition, color representation correction, and rendering.

We designed a taxonomic sample of feathers to represent a broad range of both type of bird and visual appearance of feather and collected cataloged specimens of these to use in our work as well as to make data available for other researchers and the public via an open website.  The dataset includes photographs, scanning electron microscope images, and reflectance information gathered under varying viewing and illumination angles.  This information was also used during the project to inform the development of a new shader-based method that considers barbule location on feathers for increasing visual detail in rendering with less geometry, as the small barbules of feathers are not usually represented in geometric models for computer graphics.  

This project enabled completion of a custom illumination sphere and the design and development of a novel motorized universal stage to orient and track samples within it, resulting in the Variable Illumination Sphere (VarIS) system.  The elements of these have been published to aid other researchers, and it will be used in ongoing projects related to material light-scattering data collection as well as gathering 3D data of human faces and other objects via photometric techniques and automated photogrammetry that the unique hybrid system enables.

In order to tackle challenging problems associated with measuring feathers’ reflectance patterns or those of other biological or man-made surfaces, new methods have been developed.  Prior to radiometric estimation of reflectance measurements, capture systems like VarIS require elaborate calibration.  For color calibration, we demonstrated the over-reliance of existing methods on a limited number of reference blocks from a color chart. To overcome the overfitting issues of existing approaches, we developed a statistical method to calibrate captured images with the same color-chart reference but with lower noise, higher consistency, and improved robustness.  After geometric and colorimetric corrections, resulting images from capture systems may still retain baked-in effects of the illuminant spectral power distribution. We developed a proof of concept method that allows for dynamic calibration of such with the ubiquitous compact disc as a calibration reference.  This practical method can aid accurate, radiometric estimation of spectral reflectance in material acquisition setups and inverse-rendering research.  

New methods for collecting, classifying, and analyzing light-scattering information across a spatially varying surface have also been developed during the project.  These include extending adaptive parameterization techniques for measuring bidirectional reflectance distribution functions (BRDFs) to aid in capture and representation of spatially varying BRDFs (SVBRDFs); use of distribution metrics to classify and group the Visible Normal Distribution Function (VNDF) estimated at points on a surface to reduce capture passes of a device and aid in analysis; and a hierarchical approach to clustering imaging and distribution data to accelerate processing and develop tabular data to represent VNDFs and BRDFs across the spatial surface of a sample.  These techniques may be used further in rendering physically based materials as well as studying, analyzing, and replicating the patterns represented by real-world surface reflectance of a broad variety of materials beyond feathers.

The data produced through this project can have application to studies of avian feather biomechanics in both living and extinct species of birds and subsequent correlations with avian ecology and ethology.  Observations made by analyzing feather images as well as from the development of graphical models can yield insight into comparisons of the appearance of living birds and other dinosaurs.  Data collected during this project can be repurposed to further study feather iridescence, pigments, and associated anatomical microstructures, an expanding sub-field in ornithology.  The interdisciplinary efforts of this project have also inspired other researchers in computer-graphics to concentrate on the complex structural elements of feathers and how both ray-optics and wave-optics appearance models may be built to represent them. 

The project has also contributed to building significant infrastructure that will enable further research related to material acquisition, computer graphics, computer vision, and other interdisciplinary projects.  Lastly the project has also broadened participation in computing by directly supporting or enabling mentorship and research opportunities for 4 Ph.D. students, 3 NSF Research Experience for Undergraduate student researchers, 2 M.F.A students, 1 M.S. student, and 2 high-school students.
